Answer: The natural habitat of the human genus (including the many species that went extinct) was the same woodlands where chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutan can live.People could not have naturally lived in the grasslands, as they would have found no food (they do not eat grass, just like the chimps or gorillas do not eat grass). They would eat leaves and fruits and tubers, but not grass as such. And they would be eaten by the big cats that prowl the grasslands to hunt on herbivores (grass-eaters).Of course people could not have lived in the flood plains where they would simply drown to death.In theThe natural habitat of the human genus (including the many species that went extinct) was the same woodlands where chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutan can live.People could not have naturally lived in the grasslands, as they would have found no food (they do not eat grass, just like the chimps or gorillas do not eat grass). They would eat leaves and fruits and tubers, but not grass as such. And they would be eaten by the big cats that prowl the grasslands to hunt on herbivores (grass-eaters).Of course people could not have lived in the flood plains where they would simply drown to death.In the natural habitat, there is room for no more than 25000 people. That is the number they had for the first 180000 years after they emerged on the planet. But their numbers increased when they invented animal husbandry to go to grasslands. question: https://www.quora.com/What-ecological-niche-do-humans-without-any-advanced-technology-or-agriculture-inhabit

Answer: It depends a bit on how advanced, but since you seem to include agriculture in this category, it’s basically as scavengers, then hunter-gatherers with a sideline in mass-slaughter hunting. Mass-slaughter hunting techniques (herding/luring animals to their deaths, often in crude traps) appear to be somewhat instinctive to humans, the adaptation of bipedal walking seems to have been significantly driven by it’s utility for such hunting methods, and humans seem to have an instinct for harassing animals in this way.These tendencies, even more than technology, are why many animals that are physicalIt depends a bit on how advanced, but since you seem to include agriculture in this category, it’s basically as scavengers, then hunter-gatherers with a sideline in mass-slaughter hunting. Mass-slaughter hunting techniques (herding/luring animals to their deaths, often in crude traps) appear to be somewhat instinctive to humans, the adaptation of bipedal walking seems to have been significantly driven by it’s utility for such hunting methods, and humans seem to have an instinct for harassing animals in this way.These tendencies, even more than technology, are why many animals that are physically more immediately dangerous than humans nevertheless ended up with an instinctive fear of humans. Predators especially avoid humans cause in the past it likely resulted in humans exterminating entire populations in retaliation by mass-slaughter hunting. Modern humans are a bit more selective, but still are highly intolerant of man-eating animals.The techniques of mass-slaughter hunting evolved into ranching herds of domesticated animals, or what we call pastoralism. Gathering developed into agriculture in the same way, only domesticating plants rather than animals. It’s not entirely clear which came first because the first instance of each were probably during short interglacial periods before the worst bit of the last Ice Age, making finding evidence a bit difficult.Mass-slaughter hunting techniques seem like they would be especially useful during periods of heavy glaciation, when preserving meat over long periods of time was relatively simple. It’s important to remember that most of the time modern humans have existed has been during periods of heavy glaciation.

Answer: We are not “smarter.” We are just better educated and equipped and knowledgeable in a different way. Armed with your iPhone, even just 20 years ago, you may have legitimately been the smartest person on earth! But smarts isn’t just being able to bloviate legibly on Quora. Try living on only what you can gather or grow or catch. Without firearms. Or electricity. Or running water. Or any education. Or effective medicine and doctors. Or even a lighter! Folks back then would not think I was “smarter” - they would think I was a complete idiot who couldn’t last a week. And they would be correct.

Answer: It is well established that short people are smarter than tall people. Here is how you can tell: take any two people of different height and measure their intelligence. Use an IQ test or see if they can fit a square peg into a round hole, etc. Measure each one and then divide their height into their IQ number. You will always get a larger number for the shorter person, proving yet again that short people are not only smarter than tall people but even better looking.

Answer: Evolution is such a fundamentally slow process that human beings haven’t evolved since before the time of the Pharaohs.If you took an average human from the time of the Pharaohs and compared them to an average human today, there would be many differences. Humans today are taller, stronger, and heavier than back then; mostly because we are better nourished and therefore grow more fully. We also live longer because of clean water, good housing, and the availability of medical care.But none of this is due to evolution! These are all a result of environmental changes, not changes in DNA.

Yes, we convert Energy into Power by ”boiling the water,“ which has a low energy conversion rate. Regardless of the current thermal power or nuclear power, it is heating water: heat converts water into steam, and the steam drives the turbine to generate electricity. (Note: The conversion rate of nuclear fission we use today is only 0.135%)It is most likely that human beings will not be able to "go out" the solar system, and even be "trapped" to die on earth!The nuclear fusion conversion rate is 0.7%. If nuclear fusion power generation is realized, it may alleviate the current energy crisis. It is not enough for interstellar flight. (Note: As science fiction says that "Positive and Anti-Matter Annihilation" is the most efficient, can achieve 100% quality conversion, can help us fly out of the solar system. )Realistically, if we fail to master the controllable nuclear fusion before depleting fossil energy, it is not only "Civilization Retrogression," but the entire human sci and tech civilization will be "locked out" until we die. Because in those days we will be unable to "organize higher-scale industrialization" and not be able to further test our scientific theory.Human beings are powerless and insignificant. Think of Traveler 1, the man-made object farthest from the Earth, and the fastest man-made object. It takes 40,000 years to fly to the AC+79 3888 star of Ophiuchus. It takes 73,600 to fly to Proxima Centauri of Centaur. The interstellar voyage for it is just a simple fantastic lies. How negligible us? Please be humble~As for interstellar travel, if the person who does not wear the spacesuit leaves the surface layer, just like "The deep sea fish leave the deep sea will detonate himself", yes, in any other environment, the human body will be vulnerable to "cannot withstand even a single blow". Hey, we humans are the creatures born in the surface environment. We are destined to be inseparable from such environment, and it is even more difficult to cross the "space measured by light years." The earth is the cradle of humankind and it will surely be our destination and cemetery.Almost all of the Earthian is still bound by gravity, and it is difficult to fly out of it.Humans used to go to the moon with "The primeval Chemical Rocket," but never went to Mars. Most people are trapped in the earth's tiny plot of land, let alone the universe.Although we can now "observe dozens of billions of light years of the universe", no matter how influential bigwigs can't leave the earth. They can only be like the common people who feet can't leave the ground. Exhausting the limits of the power of human tech can barely enough landing on the moon, its number can be counted on the fingers of one hand.The natural resources in the universe are inexhaustible, but we can only divide into some hostile factions, scheme against each other, intrigued, mutual suspicion, resorting to deception… excessive competition for such a little bit of unremarkable resource on earth. The human civilization at this stage is still too primitive.I really want to "strive for the cause of human civilization in the universe all my lifetime", but now I can only "work for the sake of making a living and fortune", such a life is not reconciled.We even have not been able to explore the earth.In terms of crustal exploration, the deepest borehole that our drilled has just reached more than 10,000 meters depth. Our drill bit with difficulty went to the bottom of the crust for humans and took a look at the edge of the mantle. This depth is only equivalent to "The worm takes a bite of apple peel." This is why we cannot predict earthquakes because even the "normal state" of the crust can only be inferred by indirect evidence, and the judgment of its "abnormal state" is even more unreliable.…SummaryIt seems that some of today inventions of "redoubtable and formidable" are mostly the advancement of Applied Science, not the progress of Basic Science. The development of personal computers is only consistently integrated and shrinking smaller, supercomputers are always stacking and piled up, naturally, their computing performance is strengthened…But quantitative change is unlikely to trigger a qualitative change. It won't bring us quantum computers.The so-called "innovative tide and creative spoondrift" is just something "in application-level." Basic theory has been stagnant for a long time, and superstring theory has not progressed for many years. In any case, "Basic Theory" is the "source power" of human sci and tech development. Tomorrow, we may have some room for growth in the application of tech, but the development of the "fundamental power" has not been reformed for a long time!Chier Hu's answer to Has fundamental physics stagnated?Chier Hu's answer to Do you think our technology is primitive?Chier Hu's answer to Why is medical technology so primitive compared to computer technology?Chier Hu's answer to What are some examples showing how underdeveloped or powerless present-day human technology is?

Answer: I’m going to be bold here. There isn’t one. We’re done waiting for biological evolution.Biological evolution needs two things to work:Examples of recent physiological changes in humans that I can think of right now include adult tolerance to lactose, semi-resistance to widespread diseases (malaria, bubonic plague, smallpox), and increased height.Lactose tolerance came for a time and place in which, if you couldn’t drink milk, you would likely starve. Resistance to diseasesI’m going to be bold here. There isn’t one. We’re done waiting for biological evolution.Biological evolution needs two things to work:Examples of recent physiological changes in humans that I can think of right now include adult tolerance to lactose, semi-resistance to widespread diseases (malaria, bubonic plague, smallpox), and increased height.Lactose tolerance came for a time and place in which, if you couldn’t drink milk, you would likely starve. Resistance to diseases came from time in which such diseases killed a sizable chuck of the population who weren’t resistant. And height doesn’t even count; give a human from today a crappy ancient diet and they’d end up shorter anyway.This is not a great system for improvement.We had a good run with biological evolution! Billions of years of mutating, trial-and-error, surviving, and a huge amount of premature death, and we ended up with a decent hand. But we’re done being nature’s plaything. We’ve realized that what we can do with our minds — learning, teaching, knowledge and wisdom — is a far more powerful thing that what an extra enzyme can do. And, for good for for bad, we are tantalizingly close to cutting evolution out of the process entirely and fixing our genes ourselves.

Most people don't know much about it, it is a sister unit of BARC. DAE has many units, e.g. BARC, HWB, AMD, TIFR, HIt is one of the biggest government campus(760 hectares or ~1900 acres) in the country and within city limits of Indore, the financial capital of Madhya Pradesh also known as mini- Mumbai.The campus is clean, well maintained, spacious and full of amenities (e.g. mini-mall, fruit and vegetable market, bank, school, hospital, parks, lakes etc) for the residents.RRCAT is an unit of DAE(Department of Atomic Energy), directly under the control of the honorable Prime Minister of India. Most people don't know much about it, it is a sister unit of BARC. DAE has many units, e.g. BARC, HWB, AMD, TIFR, HBNI etc. But RRCAT is probably the best in terms of campus.To those who are preparing for government jobs: Do Not miss out on RRCAT vacancies. It is a very professional place to work. And DAE pays almost 30% extra as opposed to any other central government job of the same scale. Most people only look at the pay-scale and not the allowances admissible to specific departments. Please read about PRIS scheme of DAE, ISRO, DRDO etc.Let me attach some pictures for you:It also has an in-campus institute, HBNI for MTech/MSc and PhD. I believe the eligibility is via GATE. Majorly, RRCAT is involved in non-nuclear research, e.g. lasers, particle accelerators etc. In case you get the chance, please visit it once.Thank You.P.S. There are other campuses of similar size in the country, but they are either in smaller places or outside the city.

Answer: Well, that’s a difficult question to answer, however I’ll help how I can.First off, let’s consider something for a second. The USA is in the midst of a massive stock market crash, has incredibly high unemployment, and Mr. Roosevelt is attempting to restore the economy.Britain, on the other hand, has recovered somewhat from the ‘War to end all Wars,’ and is attempting to de-escalate the tensions in Europe between Italy, Germany, and France.Overall, the UK has access to far more resources. They occupy over 1/6 of the globe, with Canadian Lumber, metals from Africa, and of course major trade hubsWell, that’s a difficult question to answer, however I’ll help how I can.First off, let’s consider something for a second. The USA is in the midst of a massive stock market crash, has incredibly high unemployment, and Mr. Roosevelt is attempting to restore the economy.Britain, on the other hand, has recovered somewhat from the ‘War to end all Wars,’ and is attempting to de-escalate the tensions in Europe between Italy, Germany, and France.Overall, the UK has access to far more resources. They occupy over 1/6 of the globe, with Canadian Lumber, metals from Africa, and of course major trade hubs in the Pacific. Further, the UK has the largest navy in the world and can afford to hire more scientists. Contrast with the USA which is collapsing in on itself and slowly but surely drifting into isolationism.The United Kingdom of England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland wins by a long shot. If you don’t include the crown colonies, the UK is incredibly dense, has the Midlands which are an industrial heartland, and is constantly innovating. The USA has New York and Washington, D.C. Everywhere else at the time is pretty much farmland. While many inventions would come out of the United States, the simple fact of the matter is: until the US economy was patched and Hitler took over Europe, the UK was always more advanced than the US of A.

Answer: The US is the most technologically advanced nation there ever was, so obviously not! I had the privilege of living there for 4 years in the 90s. It was a little like a sci-fi movie when someone gets transported to the future - I would just wander about gazing at the technological marvels that surrounded me. Just to pick out some of the highlights:1) Domestic life - I was once visiting a friend’s house and their mother happened to be loading clothes into the washing machine. She turned to me and said, “Do you have washing machines in Scotland?” Obviously, I was forced to admit, that no we didn’The US is the most technologically advanced nation there ever was, so obviously not! I had the privilege of living there for 4 years in the 90s. It was a little like a sci-fi movie when someone gets transported to the future - I would just wander about gazing at the technological marvels that surrounded me. Just to pick out some of the highlights:1) Domestic life - I was once visiting a friend’s house and their mother happened to be loading clothes into the washing machine. She turned to me and said, “Do you have washing machines in Scotland?” Obviously, I was forced to admit, that no we didn’t. Instead we just went down to the river and bashed our clothes off rocks to clean them.2) Transport - I spent two weeks in the lovely town of Columbia. Missouri. There I amazed the locals with my insistence on using a strange outmoded form of transport known as “walking”. Locals would slow down as they passed in their modern cars, pointing and laughing. To them, it must have been like watching a live action version of the Flintstones.3) Voting – would you believe it, but in the UK we still vote by drawing a little X next to the candidate we want to vote for. No sign of the advanced electronic voting they have over in the states. Indeed, we are so old fashioned that we haven’t even outsourced our voting to the Russians yet!4) Guns – It may be hard for an American to believe but almost nobody in the UK owns their own guns. This means that if we have to rise up and overthrow our own government (currently seems like a good plan) then we will be armed with nothing more than some particularly well sharpened sarcasm.Still, perhaps one day we can hope to be as advanced as the US. And there is some hope, as we now have our very own version of Donald Trump as PM!4K

Answer: The UK didn't have the industrial capacity to mass produce such technology. So the proximity fuze, radar, penicillin, jet engines, etc. were turned over to Uncle Sam with the proviso they get shipments of the devices. Proximity fuzes and radar went to Raytheon in Cambridge Massachusetts. Antibiotics went to Pfizer in Brooklyn New York. Jet engines went to General Electric in Schenectady New York. However Uncle Sam really screwed the Brits over the nukes.The UK didn't have the industrial capacity to mass produce such technology. Answer: In a few areas, actually. First is infrastructure. The Chinese planned waaaaaaaaaay ahead while building. That’s why there were ghost cities. The developers built huge communities before they were needed, knowing that large factories were coming soon. Above that is public transportation. Smaller cities have buses available that will take you just about everywhere within the city and bigger cities have subways as well as buses. For going between cities and provinces, China has a high speed rail system in place that is more extensive than the American highway system! For example: I lived in a ciIn a few areas, actually. First is infrastructure. The Chinese planned waaaaaaaaaay ahead while building. That’s why there were ghost cities. The developers built huge communities before they were needed, knowing that large factories were coming soon. Above that is public transportation. Smaller cities have buses available that will take you just about everywhere within the city and bigger cities have subways as well as buses. For going between cities and provinces, China has a high speed rail system in place that is more extensive than the American highway system! For example: I lived in a city called Nanjing in China - about 200 miles/300 km from Shanghai. I could take a high speed train from Nanjing to Shanghai in about 1.5 hours!In contrast, I took an Amtrak train from Detroit to Chicago (about 300 miles/480 km) and it took over 8 hours!Another area China wins at is public utilities. They provide electricity, water, and gas for billions of people for very affordable prices! I paid maybe a total of $20 (US) per month for all utility bills, whereas it cost me over $100 in America! Atop of that is wireless technology (which is considered a public utility in China). I paid 100 rmb ($15) monthly for 16 GB of 4G data, with 1000 texts and 500 minutes of talk (which pretty much meant unlimited everything for me). In America I pay $50 a month for my unlimited plan. Yes, the 4G is a little faster, but that may just be because I’m not trying to access the foreign web here…A third area (kinda related to the second) is how the CCP controls markets and prices so everyone can live a comfortable life. I ate a big plate of food at a small restaurant for between 10 and 20 rmb… ($1.25-2.50). The government controls the means of production, so there is plenty of food for everyone!I hope you enjoyed my answer!

Answer: Definitely the United Kingdom.The British were the world’s greatest empire in the 19th Century in part because they spent lavishly on technology, including weapons technology. That tradition of experimentation and research carried through into the monumental changes in warfare between 1914 and 1918. Only Germany and France were as invested in the machinery of war as Great Britain.The United States Army and Navy did their best to keep up with European research into weaponry, but never with the scale of funding the European powers managed. The American army, in particular, was low on every politDefinitely the United Kingdom.The British were the world’s greatest empire in the 19th Century in part because they spent lavishly on technology, including weapons technology. That tradition of experimentation and research carried through into the monumental changes in warfare between 1914 and 1918. Only Germany and France were as invested in the machinery of war as Great Britain.The United States Army and Navy did their best to keep up with European research into weaponry, but never with the scale of funding the European powers managed. The American army, in particular, was low on every political faction’s priority list and low on personnel. It built up a modern war college and a modest educational system for officers after the Spanish-American War, but a great deal of the organization it needed to fight in the Great War had to be created from scratch in 1917. For the most part, instead of developing its own technology, it had to purchase and adapt systems and equipment from France and Britain.Americans flying the British Sopwith Camel in 1918

Answer: Outside of the military there was no real sense of competition between the nations of the first world in ‘technology’. It wasn’t even a household word in Britain or the US. The most advanced non-military technology was available universally to any who could afford it regardless of nationality or where elements were invented- just as now.Militarily I can only speak of aviation. The two nations were absolutely neck-and-neck by 1939. The UK’s aerofoil aerodynamics were ahead but our drag mitigation was behind. Our in-line engines were ahead but our raduals were behind. Our radat and radio were ahOutside of the military there was no real sense of competition between the nations of the first world in ‘technology’. It wasn’t even a household word in Britain or the US. The most advanced non-military technology was available universally to any who could afford it regardless of nationality or where elements were invented- just as now.Militarily I can only speak of aviation. The two nations were absolutely neck-and-neck by 1939. The UK’s aerofoil aerodynamics were ahead but our drag mitigation was behind. Our in-line engines were ahead but our raduals were behind. Our radat and radio were ahead but our de-icing was behind.. Our propeller blades were ahead but our pitch-change mechanisms were behind.My point is that in a dynamic field of technology it is impossible to state simplistically who was ‘ahead’ nationally.
